Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Onshore-offshore MT Investigation of Cascadia Margin 3D Structure, Segmentation and Fluid Distribution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since their discovery nearly a decade ago, Episodic Tremor and Slip (ETS) events have been intensively studied along the Japan margin and in the Cascadia subduction zone of the US Pacific Northwest. These deformation events are now understood to occur in a transitional zone between the shallower, colder, locked seismogenic region and the down-dip, hot region where stable sliding of the subducting plate occurs. There is considerable interest in the role that fluids may play in ETS, from simply controlling rheological properties in the subducting and overriding plates to, possibly, explaining ETS dynamics through competing models ranging from permeability pumping/hydrofracturing to a continuum of rate and state frictional slip. Observed ETS temporal patterns can be replicated by numerical models with low confining pressures, consistent with elevated pore pressure along the plate interface. However, a lack of high-resolution geophysical imaging at depth has inhibited our ability to map the baseline distribution of fluids along subduction zones exhibiting ETS. Since magnetotelluric (MT) data are highly sensitive to the presence and connectivity of fluids, they offer the best strategy for mapping the fluid distribution within the subduction zone, and for testing the competing ETS hypotheses (e.g. friction vs. fluids).

The Magnetotelluric Observations of Cascadia using a Huge Array (MOCHA) project entails acquiring high-resolution onshore and offshore MT soundings that can be used to image deep electrical conductivity structure. Images thus derived impart knowledge of the fluid distribution and the segmentation of the convergent margin that is associated with the subducting slab along the coasts of Oregon and Washington. MOCHA consists of 60 marine and 75 land MT stations covering a 400 km section of the forearc along the north to south Siletzia terranes. The MOCHA data will ultimately constrain 3D models of the crust and upper mantle of the subduction system, from the incoming plate to the magmatic arc, revealing the distribution of fluids in the subduction system in unprecedented detail. These models will detail the offshore fluid input to the system and the distribution of fluids released from the down-going slab, including along the transitional zone where ETS occurs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

NSF support for this project has made it possible to address the near absence of high-resolution knowledge of the electrical properties of the crust and upper mantle along the Cascadia margin of Washington, Oregon and northern California. This is a region where the down-going Juan de Fuca and Gorda oceanic plates subduct beneath the overriding North American plate. The Cascadia margin is at high risk for damaging subduction zone "megathrust" earthquakes, which occur in this area every ~300-600 years.

The edge of the continent in this region is segmented into semi-rigid crustal blocks. These are bounded and interspersed with deep crustal faults. Some of the accumulated stress as these plates converge is taken up in slow, episodic tremor and slip events along the bottom boundaries of these blocks, while stress continues to build up elsewhere along the plate boundary. Much of the central Oregon continental margin is understood to be seismically locked, where stresses will continue to build up until a critical point is reached.

A key aim of this project was to provide data particularly sensitive to the distribution of fluids - both aqueous and magmatic - that may be detected if such fluids form interconnected films or channels over the scale of km or greater - by applying the magnetotelluric (MT) method. During the lifetime of this project, our team of collaborators deployed the largest amphibious MT array ever attempted, deploying 121 closely-spaced (nominally ~20-km station spacing from west-to-east) long-period MT stations on land in the region west of the Cascade volcanic arc that extended to the coastline of Washington State, Oregon and northern California. This was combined with a seafloor MT array of 57 stations, providing an array aperture sufficient to image the electrical properties of the crust and upper mantle from the down-going oceanic plates to the three primary continental coastal geological units: the North Siletzia, South Siletzia and Klamath terranes of southwest Washington and northwest Oregon, central western Oregon, and southwestern Oregon and northern California, respectively.

While the major interpretation of the data retrieved from this array is the subject of a separate NSF award, preliminary 3-D inverse modeling of the data from this effort, which was used to guide the successive waves of instrument deployment and to identify priority areas for extending the geographic coverage of the array, has led to intriguing preliminary results. We see the presence of thick fluid-rich sediments scraped from the top of the down-going oceanic plates as they accumulate along the continental margin; there is a significant change in the electrical structure along the top of the subducting Juan de Fuca/Gorda plate and at the base of the overriding mantle wedge beneath western Oregon where an absence of present-day fluids may be indicated by high electrical resistivity in this region, which corresponds to the seismically locked zone of greatest concern for inception of megathrust seismicity. There is also some correspondence between the mapped locations, at ground surface level, of what are believed to be deep crustal-scale faults in this region, and in some locations of higher electrical conductivity that may be related to channels for upward migration of slab fluids. These features are being studied in detail in a separate follow-on project, but they are firmly grounded in the data acquisition effort made by possible by this project.

Broader Impacts

From the perspective of societal relevance, the most impactful consequence of this project is important new information that helps to inform geoscientists, policy makers and the general public about the factors that may govern seismic risk in an area of high population density, critical infrastructure, and the locations of some of the most important companies in the technology sector (including semiconductors, software and services, aircraft production, etc.).

The project has also provided opportunities for students, early-career professionals, and members of traditionally underrepresented groups to learn about an important method for imaging the 3-D structure of the Earth's interior at a time when this method, MT, is emerging as a building block of multidisciplinary efforts to better understand the Earth system. The growing national capabilities to deploy MT instruments on a scale large enough to carry out ambitious land, sea and amphibious experiments builds on the capabilities and experiences of the present project, which can serve as a template for a successful, collaborative multi-institutional effort that crosses the land-sea boundary.

While entirely unexpected when this project was first proposed, another important application of high-resolution MT data over large regions is its utility in efforts to assess and mitigate risk to the electric power grid from the impacts of space weather - geomagnetic disturbances that cause geomagnetically induced currents in power transmission lines. Data from the present project have proved important in these efforts to assess such risks in the Pacific Northwest.

 


Last Modified: 03/18/2019
Modified by: Adam Schultz

Images (1 of )
  • Seafloor MT station locations installed by UCSD undercollaborative award (cyan symbols). Long-period land MTstations installed under present project support during mainphase of operations (red symbols). Array extension installedduring NCE period (purple symbols).
    Adam Schultz, Oregon State University
    Adam Schultz
    Locations of MT stations deployed under project support
  • Curved surface above top of subducting oceanic plate. Electrically conductive zones are red and resistive zones are blue. Note the resistive zone along the Oregon coastal margin that corresponds to the seismically locked zone. This model guided our 2nd wave of station installations to the S and N.
    Bo Yang, Gary Egbert, Oregon State University
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Adam Schultz
    Electrical resistivity along top of subducting oceanic plate
